justification: The package contains 10 classes with a total of 381 lines of code, which is not excessively large. The classes are functionally cohesive, focusing on IntelliJ plugin functionality for Google Java Format, and none of the individual classes exhibit excessive size or complexity that would indicate a God Component.

The package contains 76 classes with a total of 8184 lines of code, indicating a large and complex component. The class JavaInputAstVisitor alone has 3233 lines of code and 167 methods, contributing significantly to the overall size and complexity. The high number of classes and the presence of excessively large classes like JavaInputAstVisitor justify the detection of the God Component smell.

The package contains only 2 classes with a total of 102 lines of code, which is not excessively large. Neither of the classes shows indicators of being overly complex or handling too many responsibilities. The lines of code per class (49 and 53) are moderate, and the number of methods and fields is low, suggesting focused responsibilities.

The package contains 32 classes with a total of 2478 lines of code. While the package has a considerable number of classes and lines of code, the classes are logically grouped around the core functionality of code formatting. Key classes like Doc (536 LOC), OpsBuilder (504 LOC), and Newlines (159 LOC) are large but appear to encapsulate distinct responsibilities. There is no single class or component that overwhelmingly centralizes the logic or operations of the system. The distribution of responsibilities across multiple cohesive classes indicates a well-structured design rather than a God Component.

The package contains 10 classes with a total of 888 lines of code, which is not excessively large for a cohesive module handling Javadoc formatting. The largest classes (JavadocLexer with 375 LOC and JavadocWriter with 247 LOC) are specialized components with clear responsibilities. The package exhibits good internal structure and modularity without a single dominant component.
